title-group.article-title: Curing behavior and dielectric properties of amino-functionalized polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane/cyanate ester resin hybrids

article-meta.aff: 1Key Laboratory for Special Area Highway Engineering of Ministry of Education, Chang'an University, Xi'an, Shaanxi, People’s Republic of China
2Department of Polymer Engineering, Materials Engineering Institute, Soochow University, Suzhou, Jiangsu, People’s Republic of China
3Dongguan Amperex Electronics Technology Co. Ltd, Dongguan, Guangdong, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Zengping Zhang, Key Laboratory for Special Area Highway Engineering of Ministry of Education, Chang'an University, Xi'an, Shaanxi, 710064, People’s Republic of China. Email: zhangzp99@yahoo.com.cn

abstract.p: In order to improve the dielectric and overall properties of cyanate ester (CE) resin, octa(aminopropyl)silsesquioxane (POSS-NH2) was used to modify CE. A series of POSS-NH2/CE hybrids containing different contents of polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS) were elaborated by melt casting and then curing. The curing kinetics and reaction mechanisms of the resin systems were studied using Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR). Dielectric properties, thermal stability, and hot/wet resistance of the hybrids have been investigated. FT-IR results show that both temperature and POSS content may influence the curing reaction of CE. POSS-NH2 mainly displays the catalytic effect at higher temperature (220°C). Dielectric results indicate that NC1 containing 1 wt% of POSS displays not only the lowest dielectric constant but also the lowest dielectric loss. The increase in POSS content leads to significant increase in glass transition temperature (Tg) at lower POSS content (≤5 wt%). However, further increase in POSS content (>5 wt%) does not lead to great increase in Tg. Besides, all the POSS-NH2/CE hybrids show lower water absorption than that of CE.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cyanate ester (CE) resins have found more and more applications in high-frequency numeric printed circuit board (PCB), high-performance structural materials in aero and space fields owing to their excellent dielectric and mechanical properties, hot/wet resistance, and processability.1 It is well known that CE monomers are polymerized to form triazine ring and cyanate network during the curing process (Figure 1).2 However, cured CE resin consists of stiff network of triazine groups with highly cross-linking density, resulting in its brittleness that limits its application. Therefore, it has been a hot topic during the last decade to modify and toughen CE. Various additives have been used to modify CE, ranging from thermoplastics,3 thermosetting polymers4 to elastomers.5 Many nanostructured materials have also been used as modifiers for CE, such as carbon nanotubes,6 inorganic whiskers,7 Barium titanate (BaTiO3),8 and POSSs.9

Nowadays, polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS) is one of the most important nanostructured materials. It attracts much attention as one of the most important nanostructured materials owing to its excellent properties such as mechanical properties, thermal stability, and low dielectric constant.10,11 It has a particular cage structure consisting of inorganic Si-O core and external organic groups, with the molecular formula being (RSiO3/2)n, where R can be various organic groups, such as epoxy,12 amino,13 and vinyl groups.14 The octahedral POSSs usually called T8 (n = 8) is one of the most attractive POSS compounds (Figure 2).11 They have proved to be effective in improving the mechanical, thermal, and dielectric properties of many polymers. They have been used to modify various thermoplastic or thermosetting polymers, such as polyethylene,15 polypropylene,16 phenolic resin,17 polysilicone,18 polyurethane,19 epoxy,20 and polycarbonate.21 Recently, dielectric properties of POSS/polymer hybrids have attracted much attention owing to the inherently ultralow dielectric constant of POSS.22 A polyimide-based nanocomposite with a dielectric constant as low as 2.2 has been synthesized by Chen et al.23 Another polyimide/POSS nanocomposite showing a dielectric constant of 2.65 and reduced thermal expansion coefficient has also been reported.24 Benzoxazine-based polymers/POSS nanocomposites with ultralow dielectric constants have been elaborated. The dielectric constant could be reduced to about 1.9 when POSS was orientated into lamellar structures in nanometer sizes.25 More recently, a methyl-silsequioxane/CE resin (Me-SSQ/CE) hybrid with excellent dielectric properties was elaborated by our group.26 Me-SSQ/CE hybrids displayed lower dielectric constants than the pristine CE (e.g., dielectric constant is as low as 2.78 when the content of Me-SSQ in hybrid is 20 wt%).

caption.p: Structure of POSS. POSS: polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane.

sec.p: The miniaturization of high speed of electronic components requires the matrix materials with low dielectric constant and low dielectric loss.27 CE has been used as the resin matrix for high-performance PCB materials owing to its low dielectric constant and loss. Considering that POSS has extremely low dielectric constant, POSS/CE hybrid materials are expected to have excellent dielectric properties. However, the effect of POSS on the dielectric properties of thermosetting polymers including CE has not been reported to date. Besides, the reactivity of CE resins containing modifiers is vital to determine the curing techniques, even the final properties of materials.28 The effect of functional POSS on the curing reaction of CE is unclear. Thus, it is necessary to investigate the effect of POSS-NH2 on the curing behavior of CE.

One purpose of the present research is to investigate the effect of functionalized POSS monomer POSS-NH2 on the curing behavior of CE. Understanding this is important for the determination of optimum curing techniques so as to obtain the best properties of materials. The other purpose is to prepare POSS/CE hybrids with excellent dielectric properties, as is desired for a number of high-technological applications, such as PCB. In this research, the functionalized POSS monomer octa(aminopropyl)silsesquioxane (POSS-NH2) was used to modify a commonly used CE monomer of bisphenol A dicyanate (BADCy) type, 2,2′-bis(4-cyanatophenyl)isopropylidene. A series of POSS-NH2/CE hybrid systems were studied in terms of curing behavior, dielectric, and wet/hot properties.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: The BADCy (2,2’-bis(4-cyanatophenyl)isopropylidene, is white crystalline. BADCy was provided by Shanghai Huifeng Kemao Ltd. (Shanghai, China), with purity >99.5 wt%. POSS-NH2 was synthesized according to Zhang et al.29 The molecular structures of POSS-NH2 and BADCy are shown in Figure 3.

caption.p: Chemical structures of POSS-NH2 monomer and BADCy. POSS-NH2: octa(aminopropyl)silsesquioxane.

sec.title: Preparation of specimens
sec.p: BADCy was heated to melt at 100°C. Then, different amounts of POSS-NH2 were added to the melted CE. Stir the blend to be clear at 100°C and transfer it to a stainless steel mould with release agent on the inner walls, which was preheated to 120°C. Place the mould in a digital oven and degas it at 90–100°C for 20 min. The hybrid resin mixture was cured according to the following technique: 120°C/1h + 150°C/1h + 180°C /2 h. Then, allow it to cool at room temperature before the resin plaque was removed from the mould. The resin plaque underwent a free-standing postcure in a circulating air oven at 200°C for 4 h. Finally, the cured resin plates were cut into samples of required sizes (30 × 30 × 4 mm3). Five cured resin systems with different compositions were investigated. The compositions for various resin systems are listed in Table 1.

caption.p: Compositions of different CE resin systems.

sec.title: Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy and calculation of the conversion of –OCN group
sec.p: Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was performed on an IBM instrument WQF-300IR spectrometer (Beijing Beifen-Ruili Analytical Instrument Co., Ltd., P.R. China) to monitor the cure reaction. Spectra were obtained in an optical range of 400–4000cm−1 by averaging six scans at a resolution of 8 cm−1 to minimize the effects of dynamic scanning.

The content of benzene ring in all systems studied in this research does not change. Thus, the height of the peak of the benzene ring at 1500 cm−1 was adopted as the internal standard to investigate the conversion of –OCN groups at 2272 cm−1. The conversion of CE groups at time t was calculated according to equation (1).261α(t)=1−H(t)2272/H(t)1500H(0)2272/H(0)1500×100%

where α(t) is the conversion of CE resin at time t. H(t)2272 and H(t)1500 are the heights of absorption peaks of 2272 and 1500 cm−1 at time t, respectively. H(0)2272 and H(0)1500 are the heights of absorption peaks of 2272 and 1500 cm−1 at time 0, respectively.

sec.title: Dielectric properties testing and differential scanning calorimetry
sec.p: Dielectric properties of materials were measured on AS2853 Impedance analyzer (ShangHai AE Electronics Co., Ltd., P.R. China). Three frequencies (1, 5, and 50 MHz) were used to evaluate the dependence of dielectric properties on frequency. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was performed with a Perkin Elmer DSC-7 supported by a Perkin Elmer computer for data acquisition. The sample (8–10 mg) was weighed into small DSC aluminum pans and sealed with holed aluminum lids, and experiments were conducted under a nitrogen flow of 20 cm3/min. All the samples were subjected to a dynamic DSC scan from 50°C to 300°C at 10°C/min.

sec.title: Water absorption
sec.p: Three specimens of certain sizes (30 × 30 × 4 mm3) were used for water absorption testing. Before the testing, the specimens were placed at 100°C until their weights reached an asymptotic value (W0). Then the specimens were placed in boiling water. The weight gain (Wt) of each specimen due to moisture absorption was measured on a chemical balance after the removal of the moisture from the specimen surface by soft paper tissue. The moisture content was calculated as follows:Moisture content%=(Wt−W0)/W0×100%

sec.title: Curing behavior of POSS-NH2/CE hybrid systems
sec.p: The CE resin monomers will form highly cross-linking triazine groups with symmetric structure after curing. The cured CE resin possesses excellent properties such as dielectric properties, thermal stability, and hot/wet resistance. The modifiers for CE resin may influence, to some extent, the reactivity of CE. Therefore, it is necessary to investigate the effect of POSS-NH2 on the curing behavior of CE resin. In this research, a series of POSS-NH2/CE resin systems containing different amount of POSS were cured isothermally and monitored using FT-IR at 190°C and 220°C, respectively. Figure 4 is the FT-IR spectra of CE, NC1, NC2, NC3, and NC4 that were cured isothermally at 220°C. The FT-IR spectra at 190°C are not shown. In the FT-IR spectra, the absorptions at 2272 and 1500 cm−1 correspond to the vibrations of –OCN and benzene groups, respectively.26 Obviously, the absorption at 2272 cm−1 diminishes gradually with the curing time for all the hybrid resin systems. It almost disappears at the end of the curing reaction when the –OCN is fully cured.

caption.p: FT-IR spectra monitoring the curing reaction of various curing systems at 220°C. FT-IR: Fourier-transform infrared.

sec.p: Figure 5 shows the conversion of –OCN versus time for various POSS-NH2/CE resin systems at 190°C and 220°C, respectively. The conversion increases with reaction time at both temperatures. All the systems show a rapid increase in conversion within the initial 30 min. Then, conversions rise slowly and reach a stable value finally. At 220°C, the hybrid resin systems containing POSS-NH2 show faster increase in conversion with time than that of the pristine CE. It takes CE 100 min to raise the conversion to 0.9. On contrast, it takes NC1 only 40 min to reach the same conversion. Higher POSS content leads to faster increase in conversion and indicates that POSS-NH2 is able to catalyze the curing of CE at 220°C. At 190°C, however, the circumstance is more complex. NC1 and NC4 display faster increase in conversion than CE. The increase in conversion as a function of POSS content for NC2 and NC3 is similar to CE. This can be explained by the effect of POSS-NH2. POSS-NH2 mainly brings two effects to the curing reaction. One is the catalytic effect of amino groups of POSS-NH2. As is known, amines can be the catalysts for the curing of CE. The other one is the steric hindrance of POSS-NH2 with large three-dimensional molecular structure that will affect the curing reaction and limit the final conversion. Thus, the catalytic effect of POSS-NH2 is the main effect at a higher temperature (220°C). Although the complex influence of POSS-NH2 on the curing of CE at lower temperature (190°C) is attributed to the co-action of the two effects. Based on the discussion above, it is concluded that both temperature and POSS content may influence the curing reaction of CE.

caption.p: Conversion of CE versus time at 220°C and 190°C. CE: cyanate ester.

sec.title: Curing reaction between POSS-NH2 and CE and the formation of hybrid networks
sec.p: The CE resin can react with many different reactive monomers or polymers containing functional groups such as epoxy, amino, and hydroxide groups. In this research, the reaction between POSS and the resin matrix is actually the reaction between –OCN groups and the –NH2 on the vertices of POSS-NH2. In addition, when the content of POSS is low in the system, the dominant reaction should be the self-polymerization of CE monomers, that is, the formation of triazine, as shown in Figure 1. The formation of triazine ring is well known and has been studied in detail.1 Bauer and Bauer proposed the reactions between cyanates and primary amines, in 2001.2,30 They systematically discussed the chemical structures and mechanical properties of the products. On the basis of the Bauer’s study, the reaction mechanism between CE resin and POSS-NH2 is proposed, as is shown in Figure 6. It shows that initially, POSS-NH2 reacts with CE to form isourea ethers, which are transformed into bis(iminocarbonicacid ester) imides after the addition of a second cyanate. As a result, a star-like polymer is produced when the content of CE is adequate. Containing –OCN groups, they can co-cure with reactive cyanate chains to form a three-dimensional hybrid network containing POSS (Figure 7). POSS-NH2 is a kind of nanomaterial with hybrid structure. Organic groups in POSS molecules can improve its compatibility with matrix and help them to disperse in the resin matrix. At the same time, the inorganic Si-O skeleton endows the hybrids with characteristics such as good mechanical properties and thermal stability.

caption.p: The reaction between POSS-NH2 and CE resin. CE: cyanate ester; POSS-NH2: octa(aminopropyl)silsesquioxane.
Formation of the organic–inorganic hybrid structure of POSS-NH2/CE. CE: cyanate ester; POSS-NH2: octa(aminopropyl)silsesquioxane.

sec.title: Dielectric properties of POSS-NH2/CE hybrid materials
sec.p: The dielectric constant (∊) and dielectric loss are the two important indexes to characterize the dielectric properties of materials.31 ∊ is a physical quantity that evaluates the polarization extent of mediums and it is dependent on the polarities of mediums.32 Figure 8 shows the dielectric constant ∊ as a function of the POSS content for POSS-NH2/CE hybrids at different testing frequencies. ∊ first drops and then rises with increase in POSS-NH2 content. The decrease in ∊ may be attributed to two reasons. On one hand, silsesquioxanes inherently possess low ∊. Incorporation of POSS will inevitably reduce the ∊ of hybrid materials.26 On the other hand, small amount of POSS-NH2 can fill the space between polymeric chains of cyanates (NC1) and cross-link with –OCN groups as well. As a result, the regularity is enhanced, decreasing the number of movable ions and polarized ions in the resin. However, when the content of POSS-NH2 exceeds the maximum value that the intermolecular space between polymer chains can accommodate (NC2, NC3, and NC4), the excessive free POSS will exist in the resin system. Meanwhile, excessive amino groups react with –OCN to produce more branched molecular chains of cyanates. This will break the regularity of the cured resin, decreasing glass transition temperature (Tg) and increasing the number of polarized ions. As a consequence, dielectric constant is increased.

caption.p: Dielectric constant of the POSS-NH2/CE hybrids versus the content of POSS-NH2. CE: cyanate ester.

sec.p: Dielectric loss is dependent on the polarity of polymeric molecules and the density of polar groups. The higher the polarity of molecules and the density of polar groups, the higher the dielectric loss will be.32 Figure 9 displays the effect of POSS-NH2 on the dielectric loss of POSS-NH2/CE hybrids. The change in tan δ versus content of POSS is similar to that of ∊, with NC1 showing the lowest tan δ. This can be explained as follows. When the POSS content is low, with POSS filling the molecular space between polymer chains, the regularity of cured resin is high, and the molecular space is smaller in comparison with the pristine CE. The drop in movability of molecular chains and the increase in density will hinder the relaxation loss of conductive dipole segment, that is, the reduction in dielectric loss. With further increase in POSS content, the excessive POSS will inhibit the polymerization of cyanates by limiting the Mw (weight-average molecular weight) of the cured cyanates and producing more branched chains. Thus, the cured resin hybrids have poor regularity and larger space between molecular chains, which raise the dielectric loss of hybrids. It is worth noting that the hybrid systems display a dielectric loss less or slightly more than that of CE in the whole range of POSS content.

caption.p: Dielectric loss of the POSS-NH2/CE hybrids versus the content of POSS-NH2. CE: cyanate ester; POSS-NH2: octa(aminopropyl)silsesquioxane.

sec.p: In addition, the effect of frequency on the dielectric properties can be seen from Figures 8 and 9. The dielectric constants (∊) and dielectric loss (tan δ) are different at different frequencies. However, they basically show the same trend as a function of POSS contents.

sec.title: Glass transition temperature of the cured POSS-NH2/CE hybrids
sec.p: Figure 10 is the DSC curves of the cured POSS-NH2/CE hybrid materials. It can be seen that the increase in POSS-NH2 content leads to the increase in Tg of the hybrids. It shows that 1 wt% and 5 wt% of POSS-NH2 can raise the Tg of pristine CE by 17°C and 38°C, respectively. However, further increase in POSS content (>5 wt%) does not lead to significant increase in Tg. The increase in Tg results from the higher cross-link density and strong hydrogen bonding between POSS cubes and the organic molecular chains in the hybrid systems.33 Therefore, it is concluded that small amount of POSS-NH2 (≤5 wt%) can raise the Tg of CE greatly, indicating the obvious enhancement of the thermal stability of materials. Tg of hybrid materials may be increased or decreased with the increase in POSS content for different kinds of polymers, depending on a number of factors, such as types of R groups, interactions between R and polymer matrices, and cross-linking density. Although Tg of most polymers is enhanced with the incorporation of POSS, it is reduced for some systems.34,35 For the POSS-NH2/CE system, the change in Tg with POSS content can be explained by the change in cross-link densities of the hybrids. Small amount of POSS can effectively increase the cross-link densities of the hybrid network, leading to the obvious increase in Tg. However, with higher POSS loadings, the large steric hindrance of POSS molecules will raise the activation energy of the curing reaction. It will prohibit the increase in the cross-linking density to some extent. Therefore, the increase in Tg at higher content of POSS is not significant. It is similar to the POSS-NH2/Epoxy hybrid material.36

caption.p: The differential scanning calorimetric curves of the cured CE/POSS-NH2 hybrids. DSC: CE: cyanate ester; POSS-NH2: octa(aminopropyl)silsesquioxane.

sec.title: Hot/wet properties
sec.p: Water absorption is an important factor influencing the performance of CE resin and its composites, such as modulus, strength, and dielectric properties.26 Figure 11 shows the water absorption curves of POSS-NH2/CE hybrids. It can be seen that water absorption of POSS-NH2/CE hybrids is significantly lower than CE. In addition, the hybrids show lower increasing rate of water absorption as a function of boiling time. The water contained in polymeric materials can be categorized into two main forms. Some are combined with the polar groups. The others exist as free water molecules in the free volume of materials. Therefore, water absorption of POSS-NH2/CE systems is dependent on the free volume and the types and concentration of polar groups in the resin matrix. POSS-NH2 possesses symmetric structure that is nonpolar, causing little effect on the polarity of materials. Therefore, the lower water absorptions of POSS-NH2/CE hybrids are mainly due to the decrease in free volume of materials. POSS-NH2 is a nanostructured material and compatible with the resin matrix. It can fill the microvoids formed from the curing process and subsequently decrease the free volume of materials. Besides, it can be seen that NC1 shows the lowest water absorption among all the systems. Water absorption increases with the increase in POSS-NH2 content. When POSS-NH2 content is as high as 20 wt%, water absorption of the hybrid remains slightly lower than that of CE. It reveals that the hybrid materials possess better hot/wet resistance than that of pristine CE.

caption.p: Water absorption curves of the cured POSS-NH2/CE hybrids. CE: cyanate ester; POSS-NH2: octa(aminopropyl)silsesquioxane.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A series of POSS-NH2/CE hybrids containing different contents of POSS-NH2 have been prepared by melt casting and then curing. Based on the FT-IR analysis, it is concluded that both temperature and POSS content may influence the curing reaction of CE. POSS-NH2 displays mainly the catalytic effect at higher temperature. The circumstance is more complex at lower temperature. The incorporation of POSS leads to the improvement in thermal stability and hot/wet resistance. NC1 containing 1 wt% of POSS shows the best dielectric properties with not only the lowest dielectric constant but also the lowest dielectric loss. It also displays the best hot/wet resistance and indicates that POSS-NH2/CE hybrid is a potential candidate material for PCBs.

fn.p: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC) (Grant No. 51208043), China Postdoctoral Science Foundation funded project (No. 201003661), Special Fund for Basic Scientific Research of Central Colleges and the Basic Research Support Project of Chang'an University (CHD2012JC025), Key Program of Shaanxi Natural Science Foundation for Basic Research Plan (No. 2010JZ009), Program for Innovative Research Team in University (IRT1050), and Ministry of Transport Technology Project (2011319812020).
